--- title: "Ridge Regression" author: "Pierre Casadebaig" date: "2023-10-01" categories: [plotter] image: "img/preview.jpg" format: html: toc: true toc-location: left code-link: true lightbox: true --- > ### Imaginative landscapes made by stitching together random fragments of mountain ranges. Ridge Regression is a tour of imagined landscapes rooted in data visualization, drawing from real elevation logs that reveal the landscape topography of France's diverse mountain ranges. The project‚Äôs algorithm involves an evolutionary process applied to geology, where new plausible landscapes are built by recombining a set of randomly sampled real location(s).

ê´±

## Inspiration and aims Because data-based landscape representation is bound to be limited, i was researching methods or works straying away from nature imitation. Below are few artworks that really stopped me in my tracks on the design of this project. > A production of chance with a small degree of design. [Alexander Cozens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Cozens), *A New Method of Assisting the Invention in Drawing Original Compositions of Landscape*, 1785. ::: {.column-body-inset .gallery-grid}
![](img/reference/segers1638.jpg){.lightbox group="default"}
![](img/reference/hiroshige1820.jpeg){.lighbox group="default"}
::: > (left) *The Enclosed Valley*, [Hercules Segers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hercules_Seghers), c. 1625 - c. 1630. Line etching and drypoint, printed in brown on paper prepared with a light brown ground. ([source](https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/collection/RP-P-H-OB-813/catalogue-entry?pdfView=False)). > (right) *Eight Views of ≈åmi - Hira Mountains*, [Hiroshige](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroshige), 1820. Woodblock print ([source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hiroshige_Omi_Hirai.jpg)) Evolving from the [*dispyr*](/posts/process/dispyr) algorithm, where each landscape was unequivocally linked to a piece of topographical data, this project explores the creation of imaginative drawings of landscapes. On the digital side, this work stems from data visualization, drawing from real elevation data to reveal topography. But rather than aiming for a realistic rendering, the algorithm was adjusted to evoke hand-drawn landscapes. While some outputs were clearly standing out and could stand on a page by themselves, most of them would lack representativeness. Instead of discarding them, i designed rules to assemble these modest outputs, leading to the creation of synthetic yet realistic landscapes. This project also harmonized distinct algorithmic systems‚Äîsuch as ridges, writings, and clouds‚Äîvia a responsive grid layout, adapting to the shape of generated components. On the physical side, the project also explored alternatives to precise and technical pen-plotter renderings. This was achieved through coding techniques like line overlays and noise but also by using drawing tools such as brushes, calligraphic pens, and technical pens. ## Methods ### Landscape generation We start with high-resolution (5x5 m cells) data from a digital elevation model (DEM, here IGN [RGE Alti 5m](https://geoservices.ign.fr/rgealti#telechargement5m)) that represents the variations in land height in South-West France. Using the [*dispyr*](/posts/process/dispyr) algorithm, this 3D data is transformed into a series of lines that we call "elevation profiles". For each iteration, these lines can represent anything from a single horizon to a series of layered ridges, depending on where the data is sampled and how it's oriented (two random parameters). I settled for a simulation set of 3000 individual profiles, whose diversity is illustrated below. #### Classification of profiles types Working with this library of about 3000 profiles, we discard the less interesting ones and classify the remaining into two categories: flat ones that look like fields or plains, and tall ones that resemble mountains or high hills. To create and imaginary piece of landscape, we select a random mixture of profiles ‚Äî most are flat, but few are tall ‚Äî and layer them accordingly. #### Assembly rules ### Distinct aesthetics The different landscapes generated by this process are organized into a catalog. Each page of the catalog is divided into different sections, or "cells", by a generative grid system. Each cell might contain a part of a landscape, a cloud, or even texts that look like writing but don't have a specific meaning. A grid system helps us divide the page space into different sized sections, both regular and irregular proportions. We do this by splitting the space into fractions, with each division being a one-sixth multiple. At the end, we designed four page styles ranging from full-page landscapes with different physical rendering (ink brush, technical ink pen) to figure-like gridded layouts with or without legend. #### brush #### cloud #### figure #### grids ### Rendering Each style was rendered on paper (Canson mixed media, natural white, fine grain, 200 gsm) with a different set of pens : * brush pen (Pentel FL2B, black ink): ridges in the *brush* design. * calligraphy fountain pen (Lamy Joy 1.5 mm): glyphs in the *brush* design (Sailor Shikiori Yodaki red ink) and in the *cloud* design (Pilot Iroshizuku take-sumi neutral black ink). * calligraphy pens (Pilot Parallel): hatched cloud in the *cloud* design (3.8 mm, Pilot Iroshizuku fuyu-syogun medium gray ink), bold writings in the *figure* design (1.5 mm, Pilot black ink). * technical pens (Rotring Isograph): ridges in the *cloud*, *figure*, and *grids* designs (0.3 mm), frames in the *figure* and *grids* style (0.8 mm), and writings in the *figure* style (0.3 mm), all were draw with the Pilot Iroshizuku take-sumi ink. ## Selected iterations
